title: PROOF: The Affirmative Action Committee's Formation Was a Foundational Breach of the 2020 DNC MOU, Rendering It Illegitimate at Inception
stakes: The promise of representation for West Virginia's minority communities was broken at the moment of its supposed creation, disenfranchising the very groups the MOU was meant to empower and guaranteeing the failure of the entire diversity initiative.
thesis: The WVDP, under the failed supervision of the DNC's RBC, committed a foundational and irredeemable violation of the 2020 MOU by using a non-public script to install a pre-selected leadership slate before its constituent caucuses were formed, thereby creating an illegitimate committee structured to fail.

axioms.text: The Caucus-First Mandate: The MOU required that the Affirmative Action Committee be formed with members 'selected by their particular caucus.'
The State Party's Duty to Implement: The MOU mandated that the State Party 'fully implement... the creation of any new... caucuses.'
The RBC's Duty to Supervise: The MOU explicitly required that the entire implementation process be conducted 'under the supervision... of representatives of the RBC.'

rule_summary: These rules established a mandatory, non-negotiable sequence—a blueprint for legitimacy. The MOU required that caucuses be formed first to select their own representatives, who would then constitute the committee. Any other process was a direct breach of the agreement's core terms, and the RBC was the designated supervisor responsible for enforcing that blueprint.

case_facts.text: The committee's formation was orchestrated in secret using a non-public script, circulated with the explicit instruction 'do not share,' proving the process was designed to be non-transparent.

The script's author(s) proceeded with full knowledge that their plan excluded the majority of required diversity groups, as the document itself admits the committee was 'missing representation from... Latino's, Asian Americans and Pacific Islanders, and Native Americans.'
To ensure control, the script pre-emptively installed a hand-picked leadership slate, nullifying the right of the yet-to-be-formed caucuses to participate in selecting their own leadership.

The script's author, Selina Vickers, cemented procedural control by orchestrating her own self-appointment to the role of Parliamentarian, complete with a pre-written endorsement calling her uniquely qualified.

logic_chain: The MOU promised a legitimate, caucus-driven process for forming the AAC under the watchful eye of the DNC's RBC.
Instead, the State Party, guided by a secret script, deliberately subverted this promise.
This subversion was intentional, as the script's own text proves the organizers knew they were excluding 75% of the required racial diversity caucuses.
By pre-emptively installing leadership, they disenfranchised these minority groups at the committee's inception.
This foundational breach occurred under the mandated supervision of the DNC's RBC, which failed its duty to intervene and enforce the MOU's terms.
[DJ-MARK] The result was not an authentic committee, but an illegitimate body born from a rigged process, directly violating the 2020 MOU.
violation: The WVDP's implementation and the RBC's supervisory failure were not mere procedural errors; they constituted a foundational breach of contract and trust. They violated the MOU's core 'caucus-first mandate' by knowingly creating an unaccountable committee through a secretive, pre-arranged process. This initial, deliberate act of disenfranchisement rendered the Affirmative Action Committee illegitimate at the moment of its creation and doomed the entire diversity initiative to fail. The remedy required: void all actions taken by this illegitimate committee and reconstitute it properly with all required caucuses participating.

title: PROOF: WVDP Failed to Properly Implement DNC-Mandated Diversity Plan
stakes: Minority caucuses were denied their right to select committee leadership. Control went instead to a single unelected DNC appointee.
thesis: The WVDP violated the 2020 DNC MOU by installing AAC leadership before establishing the required diversity caucuses.

axioms.text: The 2020 MOU's stated purpose was 'to create a process to establish new, and assist currently existing, diversity caucuses'.
axioms.citation: 2020 MOU between WVDP and DNC RBC, p. 1

axioms.text: The MOU appointed a non-elected official, Selina Vickers, to 'oversee and direct compliance' with the agreement.
axioms.citation: 2020 MOU between WVDP and DNC RBC, p. 2

axioms.text: The Affirmative Action Committee (AAC) was required to be composed of co-chairs from 'each of the recognized diversity caucuses of the WVDP'.
axioms.citation: 2020 MOU between WVDP and DNC RBC, p. 1

rule_summary: Together, these provisions establish that diversity caucuses must exist and select their own representatives before the AAC can be properly constituted. Any AAC formed without caucus participation violates the MOU's core mandate of ensuring minority groups have a voice in party governance.

case_facts.text: The WVDP installed leadership for the Affirmative Action Committee (AAC) on June 5, 2021.
At the time of leadership installation, the majority of racial diversity caucuses did not exist.
The DNC-appointed compliance official circulated a pre-written script on June 2 that dictated the AAC's formation meeting proceedings.
case_facts.citation: Draft Script Email June 2; Selina Script

logic_chain: The DNC mandated that the WVDP establish diversity caucuses and include them in forming the AAC.
The WVDP installed the AAC's leadership on June 5, 2021, when the majority of racial diversity caucuses did not yet exist.
This pre-emptive formation excluded the yet-to-be-formed caucuses from having any voice in selecting the AAC's leadership structure.
The DNC-appointed official orchestrated this improper formation through a pre-written script.
[DJ-MARK] The WVDP and its designated compliance official violated the core diversity and inclusion requirements of the 2020 DNC MOU.
violation: The WVDP violated the 2020 DNC MOU by forming the Affirmative Action Committee and selecting its leadership before establishing the required constituent diversity caucuses, thereby disenfranchising minority groups from the foundational process. This violation undermines the MOU's purpose of ensuring full participation by minority communities in party governance.

title: PROOF: Script's Detail Proves Deliberate Exclusion of Mandated Caucuses
stakes: This action rendered the Affirmative Action Committee improperly constituted at its formation. By proceeding without 75% of its required racial diversity caucuses, the committee's foundational decisions, including the election of its leadership, lacked the mandated representation of Latino, AAPI, and Native American Democrats.
thesis: The script's exhaustive detail proves the organizers possessed the capacity for complex planning but deliberately failed to form the Latino, AAPI, and Native American caucuses, proving their exclusion was a strategic choice in violation of the DNC MOU.

axioms.text: The 2020 DNC MOU required the creation of an Affirmative Action Committee ('AA Committee') to include members from each diversity group... selected by their particular caucus.
axioms.citation: 2020 MOU between WVDP and DNC RBC, p. 2-3

axioms.text: The mandated diversity groups included African Americans, Native Americans, Asian/Pacific Islanders, and Latinos.
axioms.citation: 2020 MOU between WVDP and DNC RBC, p. 2

rule_summary: The MOU, as the governing agreement for the party's reform process, established a mandatory sequence: 1) The party must facilitate the formation of specific diversity caucuses. 2) Those caucuses must select their own representatives. 3) Those representatives must then constitute the AA Committee. The committee's legitimacy was wholly dependent on the prior existence and participation of these groups as defined in the MOU.

case_facts.text: The script for the June 2, 2021 meeting demonstrates micro-level control, dictating specific nominators (e.g., 'Mary Ann nominates Hollis Lewis'), providing verbatim speeches, and planning for procedural disruptions.

The script proves the organizers knew 75% of the racial caucuses (Latino, AAPI, Native American) did not exist, as it includes a future resolution to 'do outreach to Latinos, Asian Americans/Pacific Islanders and Native Americans to facilitate those groups in forming their own diversity caucuses'.

The script designates a specific individual, Kim Felix, to be nominated for an at-large diversity seat 'representing Latino Americans', proving the organizers had identified potential leadership for a caucus they had not yet formed.

logic_chain: The organizers demonstrated a high capacity for detailed organizational planning, as evidenced by the script.
The organizers possessed documented knowledge that the Latino, AAPI, and Native American caucuses had not been formed as required by the MOU.
The capacity to plan in minute detail, combined with the documented failure to execute the prerequisite task of forming caucuses, indicates the exclusion was intentional, not accidental.
Therefore, the decision to proceed with the AAC's formation was a deliberate choice to exclude 75% of the required racial diversity caucuses from participating in the selection of leadership.
[DJ-MARK] The organizers deliberately violated the MOU by choosing exclusion over inclusion.
violation: The organizers deliberately violated the 2020 DNC MOU by proceeding with the formation of the AAC while knowingly excluding 75% of the required racial diversity caucuses. The script's own detail proves this was a calculated act of disenfranchisement, not an administrative failure, that breached the core terms of the reform agreement.

title: PROOF: AAC Leadership Selection Was Procedurally Invalid
stakes: The committee's leadership was not selected through a fair and open process as required by party rules. This procedural invalidity calls into question the legitimacy of all subsequent actions taken by that leadership.
thesis: The AAC leadership election was conducted according to a non-public, pre-written script that dictated a pre-arranged slate of candidates, violating DNC Charter requirements for open and public procedures.

axioms.text: The DNC Charter requires the party to 'Establish standards and rules of procedure to afford all members of the Democratic Party full, timely and equal opportunities to participate in decisions concerning the selection of... officers... and the conduct of other Party affairs'.
The Democratic Party 'shall be open to all who desire to support the Party and who wish to be known as Democrats'.

rule_summary: The DNC Charter, the highest governing document of the party, requires that the procedures for officer selection be public and provide an equal opportunity for all Democrats to participate. A non-public script that pre-arranges the slate of candidates directly violates this foundational standard. A legitimate, open process would have no reason for secrecy.

case_facts.text: A script for the AAC meeting was created by Selina Vickers and circulated via email with the subject line 'DRAFT SCRIPT - do not share'.
The script dictated the nomination sequence for the co-chairs: 'Mary Ann nominates Hollis Lewis' and 'Hollis nominated Mary Thorp'.
The explicit 'do not share' instruction proves the organizers knew their process violated the party's open meeting requirements.

logic_chain: The procedure used for the election was a secret script.
This script was explicitly designated as non-public ('do not share').
The script pre-determined the slate of candidates, which does not provide an 'equal opportunity' for other potential candidates or for members to make open nominations.
A legitimate, open process would have no reason for secrecy.
Therefore, the procedure used for the election violated the DNC Charter's requirements for open and fair processes.
[DJ-MARK] The secret script proves consciousness of wrongdoing.
violation: The use of a non-public script to dictate a pre-arranged slate of candidates for AAC leadership was a direct violation of the DNC Charter. The procedure did not afford members 'full, timely and equal opportunities to participate'. The secrecy instruction proves the organizers knew they were violating the party's foundational principles.

title: PROOF: Script Author Orchestrated Her Own Appointment to a Key Role
stakes: A conflict of interest corrupted the committee's formation, as the lead Challenger for the MOU used her position as the script's author to install herself in a role with procedural authority over the committee's business, controlling meeting procedures, rules interpretations, and the official record.
thesis: The lead Challenger from the 2020 MOU, Selina Vickers, authored the meeting script and included her own nomination and a pre-written endorsement for herself to be installed in the role of Parliamentarian/Secretary.

axioms.text: The Democratic Party shall 'Encourage and support codes of political ethics... to assure that public officials shall at all times conduct themselves in a manner that reflects creditably upon the office they serve'.

rule_summary: Ethical conduct requires that an official organizing a process not use their influence to gain a position of power within that process.

case_facts.text: The script, authored by Selina Vickers, directs the newly elected co-chair Hollis Lewis to state: 'I nominate Selina Vickers for Parliamentarian/Secretary.'

The script provides a verbatim, laudatory endorsement for Hollis Lewis to read, which states Ms. Vickers was instrumental in the committee's formation and concludes, 'I can think of no one else remotely qualified to do this particular work.'
The role of Parliamentarian/Secretary controls meeting procedures, rules interpretations, and the official record of committee business.

logic_chain: The author of the meeting's script was Selina Vickers, the lead Challenger from the MOU.
The script she authored contained a pre-written nomination for herself to a key procedural role.
The script she authored also contained an effusive endorsement of her own unique qualifications to be read by another person.
This role gave her control over meeting procedures and the official record.
This constitutes an act of self-appointment, using her position as the meeting's architect to secure a position of procedural power.
[DJ-MARK] She wrote herself into power.
violation: The script documents a significant conflict of interest in which the lead Challenger from the MOU used her authority as the meeting's organizer to orchestrate her own installation into a key committee role with procedural control, violating fundamental ethical standards of fair and open processes.

title: PROOF: Script Reveals Pre-Planned Strategy to Control Meeting and Dissent
stakes: The committee was not designed to be a forum for open deliberation as required by party rules. Its procedures were structured to execute a pre-determined agenda and manage any opposition, not to foster inclusive participation.
thesis: The meeting script contained pre-planned tactics to challenge unauthorized attendees and manage anticipated criticism, proving the meeting was designed to execute a controlled plan, not to facilitate open participation.

axioms.text: The DNC Charter mandates that 'All meetings of... all other official Party committees, commissions and bodies shall be open to the public'.

rule_summary: The DNC Charter's rule for open meetings requires a process that allows for spontaneous, good-faith participation, not a pre-planned system to control who can attend and to manage anticipated opposition.

case_facts.text: The script anticipates that the meeting may be closed to the public and provides a challenge to be used against observers: 'Ask: 'I notice there are people other than caucus co-chairs present. I thought this meeting was solely for co-chairs.''
The script anticipates criticism from Party Chair Belinda Biafore, pre-characterizing it as 'scolding': 'She may scold you for the caucus meetings last night'.
The script provides response strategies for managing this anticipated opposition rather than addressing its substance.

logic_chain: The script contains a pre-planned tactic to challenge the presence of observers at what should be an open meeting.
The script anticipates opposition from the Party Chair.
It pre-characterizes this opposition as 'scolding' - trivializing legitimate concerns.
The script provides response strategies for managing this opposition.
This proves the meeting was designed to execute a pre-determined outcome despite anticipated objections.
[DJ-MARK] The organizers built opposition management into their plan, violating principles of open deliberation.
violation: The script's prepared tactics for managing participation and its pre-emptive characterization of criticism as 'scolding' violate the 'open meetings' principle of the DNC Charter. This proves the meeting was designed to control outcomes, not facilitate democratic participation.

title: PROOF: DNC Official Violated 2020 MOU by Advising Appointee on Strategy to Undermine Dissenting Committee Members
stakes: The democratic process of a state-level diversity committee was corrupted by a national party official in direct violation of a binding Memorandum of Understanding.
thesis: A DNC Rules Committee member, Harold Ickes, was documented advising a non-voting Parliamentarian to 'outvote' elected minority members, an action that directly violates both the DNC Charter and the explicit terms of the 2020 MOU he was tasked with overseeing.

axioms.text: The 2020 MOU's stated purpose was to ensure an 'open and transparent process' and provide members a 'full, timely, and equal opportunity to engage' in party affairs.
axioms.citation: 2020 MOU between WVDP and DNC RBC, p. 1

axioms.text: The MOU defined the DNC Rules & Bylaws Committee's (RBC) role as providing 'supervision and technical assistance' to ensure compliance.
axioms.citation: 2020 MOU between WVDP and DNC RBC, p. 1-2

axioms.text: Harold Ickes, a corporate lobbyist, was an appointed member of the DNC's RBC during the period this MOU was in effect.
The MOU process resulted in Selina Vickers' appointment as Parliamentarian, a non-voting position.

rule_summary: Advising a non-voting appointee on how to neutralize elected members is a direct violation of the 2020 MOU's mandate for an 'open and transparent process' and exceeds the RBC's defined role of providing 'supervision and technical assistance.'

case_facts.text: On September 23, 2021, the AAC Black Caucus Co-Chair, Mary Ann Claytor, wrote in an email that it was 'disturbing to hear Harold [Ickes] admit he advised Selina [Vickers] to 'outvote' Seth, Mari, and others'.
case_facts.citation: Email from Mary Ann Claytor, Sept. 23, 2021

logic_chain: DNC official Harold Ickes served on the RBC, the committee tasked with overseeing the WVDP reforms under the 2020 MOU.
The MOU explicitly required an 'open process' and 'full participation.'
Ickes gave strategic advice to a non-voting appointee to 'outvote' elected members from diversity caucuses.

This advice is the antithesis of an 'open process' and actively undermines 'full participation,' constituting a direct violation of the MOU's spirit and terms, and an overreach of the RBC's defined role.
violation: A DNC official from the oversight committee violated the 2020 MOU and the DNC Charter by advising a non-voting appointee on a strategy to neutralize elected members. This action exceeds the RBC's defined role of 'supervision,' corrupts the MOU's stated goal of 'full participation,' and represents an improper overreach of authority.

title: PROOF: A Coordinated Smear Campaign Was Used to Discredit and Isolate Dissenting AAC Members
stakes: The votes and voices of elected minority leaders were neutralized through a coordinated campaign of public accusations, scripted attacks, and procedural manipulation.
thesis: Following high-level advice to neutralize dissent, a coordinated public and private campaign was executed to discredit minority caucus leaders through scripted attacks, public accusations, and invalid meeting procedures.

axioms.text: The Democratic Party shall 'Encourage and support codes of political ethics... to assure that public officials shall at all times conduct themselves in a manner that reflects creditably upon the office they serve'.
The Democratic Party must conduct its affairs with the 'fullest and fairest' participation of all its members.

rule_summary: A coordinated campaign to discredit and isolate dissenting members through concealed scripting, public accusations, and improper procedures violates the DNC Charter's requirements for both ethical conduct and fair participation.

case_facts.text: The DNC-appointed official, Selina Vickers, was documented scripting a point-by-point rebuttal for another committee member to use against dissenters, with the explicit instruction to conceal her authorship: '[if you use this... DO NOT FORWARD THIS EMAIL]'.
case_facts.citation: Selina asking a Senior Caucus member to attack Seth Sturm.pdf
case_facts.url: /files/Selina asking a Senior Caucus member to attack Seth Sturm.pdf

case_facts.text: Another AAC member initiated a multi-day public campaign to discredit a dissenting member, labeling him a 'toxic bully and AA committee saboteur' and announcing a 'calendar of posts ready to go'.
An out-of-state associate presided over an AAC meeting where prior committee votes were overturned—an action later ruled a bylaw violation.
case_facts.citation: DJ Proof #003: Committee Violated DNC Mandate by Nullifying Vote to Block Caucus Chairs

logic_chain: A multi-pronged campaign was waged against dissenting members.
The campaign involved covert actions, such as scripting attacks for others to carry out while concealing the authorship.
It also involved overt actions, such as a sustained public social media campaign to label dissenters as 'bullies' and 'saboteurs'.
Finally, it involved procedural manipulation, using an invalid meeting to overturn a legitimate vote.
[DJ-MARK] The combination of covert scripting, public smears, and procedural violations proves a coordinated and unethical campaign to silence and disenfranchise specific members.
violation: A coordinated campaign of covertly scripted attacks, public smears, and procedural manipulation was used to violate the DNC Charter's requirements of ethical conduct and 'fullest and fairest' participation. This campaign created a hostile environment designed to neutralize the votes and voices of specific elected minority members.

title: PROOF: AAC Nullified Valid Vote to Exclude Minority Caucus Chairs
stakes: Indigenous and Black caucus chairs were denied subcommittee seats when leadership nullified a valid democratic vote.
thesis: AAC leadership violated the DNC MOU by nullifying a vote and excluding minority caucus chairs through an invalid meeting.

axioms.text: The WVDP failed to establish the majority of its racial diversity caucuses before the Affirmative Action Committee's leadership was elected, effectively disenfranchising those groups from the committee's formation.
axioms.citation: DJ Proof 1.02: WVDP Failed to Properly Implement DNC-Mandated Diversity Plan

axioms.text: The 2020 DNC MOU's purpose was to 'encourage full participation by all Democrats, with particular concern for minority groups'.
axioms.citation: 2020 MOU between WVDP and DNC RBC, p. 1

axioms.text: 'No person shall take part in a meeting or be an officer... unless they are a qualified registered member of the Democratic electorate of the political subdivision in which they participate'.
axioms.citation: Resolution of the Board of Appeals, Nov. 29, 2021

rule_summary: The DNC MOU requires encouraging full participation by minority groups in all committee activities. When combined with party bylaws requiring proper meeting procedures, any action that excludes minority representatives through invalid proceedings violates both the letter and spirit of the diversity mandate.

case_facts.text: First, the full committee democratically voted to allow any member to join subcommittees by volunteering.
case_facts.citation: Grievance, Claytor, Sturm, and Sturm v. Thorp and Vickers, Para. 59

case_facts.text: Following this vote, leadership refused to honor it and denied subcommittee seats to the chairs of the Indigenous and Black caucuses.
A small subcommittee then rewrote the rules to replace the full committee's volunteer system with restrictive requirements.
An out-of-state parliamentarian presided over the meeting that passed these restrictive rules.
The party's Appeals Board subsequently ruled this meeting violated bylaws due to the out-of-state parliamentarian.
case_facts.citation: Resolution of the Board of Appeals, Nov. 29, 2021

logic_chain: The DNC mandated that the AAC encourage full participation from minority caucuses.
The full committee voted democratically for an inclusive volunteer system for subcommittees.
Leadership refused to implement this vote and specifically excluded the Indigenous and Black caucus chairs.
Leadership then used a procedurally invalid meeting to impose restrictive rules that formalized this exclusion.
The party's own Appeals Board confirmed the meeting violated bylaws.
[DJ-MARK] This pattern—first delaying caucus formation, then denying subcommittee access through invalid procedures—systematically violated the DNC MOU's inclusion mandate.
violation: AAC leadership violated the 2020 DNC MOU by nullifying a democratic vote and using a procedurally invalid meeting to exclude minority caucus chairs from subcommittees. This violation represents a systematic pattern of disenfranchisement that defeats the MOU's core purpose of ensuring minority participation in party governance.

title: PROOF: A Pattern of Ghostwriting Reveals a Deliberate Strategy to Feign Organic Action and Exert Undue Influence
stakes: The committee's democratic process was a fiction; key outcomes, from its initial formation to its internal disputes, were secretly scripted by a single, unelected appointee to create the illusion of consensus.
thesis: A comparison of documents from the AAC's formation and a later internal dispute reveals a consistent pattern: the DNC-appointed compliance official repeatedly ghostwrote scripts and statements for other members, complete with instructions to conceal her authorship, proving a deliberate strategy to manufacture seemingly organic support for her agenda.

axioms.text: The DNC Charter requires 'full, timely and equal opportunities to participate in decisions concerning... the conduct of other Party affairs'.

The Democratic Party shall 'Encourage and support codes of political ethics... to assure that public officials shall at all times conduct themselves in a manner that reflects creditably upon the office they serve'.

rule_summary: Party rules and basic ethical principles require that committee actions and member statements be authentic expressions of the democratic will. A pattern of a single official scripting events for others and instructing them to hide her involvement fundamentally violates the principle of fair, open, and ethical participation.

case_facts.text: Instance 1 (June 2021): For the AAC's formation meeting, Selina Vickers authored and circulated a detailed script that dictated nominations, included a pre-written endorsement for her own self-appointment, and was sent with the instruction 'do not share'.
case_facts.citation: Email circulating the AAC formation script

case_facts.text: Instance 2 (August 2021): During an internal committee dispute, Selina Vickers authored and sent a point-by-point rebuttal for another senior caucus member to use against a dissenter, with the explicit instruction '[if you use this... DO NOT FORWARD THIS EMAIL]'.
case_facts.citation: Email scripting an attack for a senior caucus member
case_facts.url: /files/Selina asking a Senior Caucus member to attack Seth Sturm.pdf

case_facts.text: Instance 3 (November 2021): Another caucus co-chair publicly testified that Vickers and other leaders engaged in 'Writing scripts for white members used during AAC meetings in an effort to gain and whip majority votes on actions meant to silence dissenting BIPOC members'.

logic_chain: In three separate, high-stakes situations, the same unelected official took the same covert action.
In each instance, she secretly ghostwrote detailed text for another member to use or orchestrated events.
In two of those instances, she gave explicit instructions to conceal her authorship ('do not share' and 'DO NOT FORWARD'). The third instance was exposed by a public witness statement.
A single instance could be an anomaly. Three documented instances prove a deliberate and repeatable pattern of behavior.
This pattern demonstrates a clear strategy to subvert the democratic process by making orchestrated actions appear to be organic.
[DJ-MARK] This was not authentic committee deliberation; it was a series of puppet shows with a single, hidden director.
violation: The documented pattern of ghostwriting and concealing authorship constitutes a severe and repeated violation of the DNC Charter's principles of fair, open, and ethical participation. It demonstrates a calculated strategy to subvert the democratic process by manufacturing the illusion of organic consensus, thereby exerting undue and illegitimate influence over the committee's actions and outcomes. This pattern proves the committee was never a genuine forum for minority voices, but a controlled entity designed to execute a pre-determined agenda from its very inception.

title: PROOF: Private PAC Used Official Party Resources Without Disclosure
umbrella_category: A New Day PAC Campaign Finance Violations
stakes: One PAC gained exclusive access to party resources while hiding this subsidy from public disclosure.
thesis: A party officer's PAC used an official email list without reporting the required in-kind contribution.

axioms.text: Any 'thing of value' provided to a political committee must be reported as an in-kind contribution.
The 'countychairs@wvdemocrats.com' email list is a valuable, restricted party asset and its use constitutes a 'thing of value'.

rule_summary: Campaign finance law requires political committees to report any 'thing of value' they receive as an in-kind contribution. Access to a restricted party email list for fundraising purposes clearly constitutes such value and must be disclosed.

case_facts.text: A promotional email for the private 'A New Day' PAC was sent using the official WVDP County Chairs email list on August 22, 2023.
case_facts.citation: A New Day Training Email, Aug 22, 2023

case_facts.text: The PAC's sworn Q3 2023 financial report covering this period reported $0.00 in in-kind contributions received from any source, including the party.
case_facts.citation: A New Day PAC Q3 2023 Filing, p. 1

logic_chain: The official WVDP County Chairs email list is a valuable, restricted resource.
A New Day PAC used this resource on August 22, 2023, to solicit funds and participation.
State law requires reporting any 'thing of value' received as an in-kind contribution.
The PAC's sworn Q3 2023 financial disclosure reported zero in-kind contributions.
[DJ-MARK] The PAC concealed its use of party resources by failing to report the required in-kind contribution.
violation: A New Day PAC violated state campaign finance law by failing to report the WVDP email list usage as an in-kind contribution in its Q3 2023 filing. This violation conceals improper subsidization of a private PAC with party resources and denies the public transparency about the true sources of political influence.
potential_remedies: File a corrected report disclosing the source and fair market value of the in-kind contribution.
Reimburse the WVDP for the fair market value of its email list usage.
Establish a clear party policy prohibiting use of party resources by external PACs.

title: PROOF: Unreported Financial Activity - The Scholarship Program
umbrella_category: A New Day PAC Campaign Finance Violations
stakes: A PAC concealed its scholarship program from required disclosures, hiding who funded it and who benefited.
thesis: A New Day PAC failed to report any financial activity for its formal scholarship program.

axioms.text: All expenditures made by a political committee must be publicly reported.
Any 'thing of value' received by a political committee must be publicly reported as an in-kind contribution.

rule_summary: State law requires political committees to report all financial transactions—whether expenditures or in-kind contributions. A scholarship program necessarily involves one or both types of reportable transactions. Failure to report either violates campaign finance law.

case_facts.text: A New Day PAC solicited applications for a formal scholarship program for third-party training on August 22, 2023.
The PAC's Q3 2023 sworn financial report shows zero expenditures to the trainer for scholarship payments.
case_facts.citation: A New Day PAC Q3 2023 Filing

case_facts.text: The same sworn report shows zero in-kind contributions from the trainer for donated training slots.
case_facts.citation: A New Day PAC Q3 2023 Filing

case_facts.text: The PAC had previously paid this same trainer for 'Consultant Fees' in Q4 2022, establishing a documented financial relationship.
case_facts.citation: A New Day PAC Q4 2022 Filing

logic_chain: The PAC publicly offered scholarships for training on August 22, 2023.
Any scholarship transaction constitutes either an 'expenditure' or a 'thing of value' that must be publicly reported under state law.
The PAC's sworn Q3 2023 financial report contains neither expenditures for scholarships nor in-kind contributions of training slots.
The absence of any reported transaction means the PAC concealed this program from required public disclosure.
[DJ-MARK] The PAC's sworn financial disclosure reports omit all activity related to its scholarship program.
violation: A New Day PAC violated state campaign finance law by failing to report the financial activity of its scholarship program in its Q3 2023 filing. This violation denies the public its statutory right to transparency in political financing and renders the PAC's sworn statement materially incomplete.
potential_remedies: File a corrected report that accurately discloses all financial activity related to the scholarship program.
Provide a public accounting of how the scholarship program was funded and who the recipients were.
Cease all financial activities until the committee's reporting can be brought into compliance.
